text: I don’t think it’s really the same. Also keep in mind that a lot of the MLIR experimentation (on the LLVM side) is to make high-level IR optimizations easier and re-usable. E.g. they basically saw the need for infrastructure which is re-usable since so many languages/compilers were implementing mid-level IRs

text: Yea, it's definitely not the same...but I think similar in some ways. Programs are being pushed into the compiler, so at some point you hit a hard boundary, where you need to switch

text: It's not going to be as easy as being done in Julia, but I get the limitations and tradeoffs

elements.text: It's not going to be as easy as being done in Julia, but I get the limitations and tradeoffs

text: I think the idea would be to re-use all the infrastructure already in place. Ideally, it would be like using the CUDA compiler.

text: E.g. not a huge deal. There are still non-trivial problems to solve to make it that way, however.
